articles.headline: Obama Says U.S. Will Pursue Thaw With Cuba
articles.snippet: President Obama’s overture to Cuba at a gathering of Western Hemisphere leaders in Trinidad capped a dizzying series of diplomatic developments this week.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s overture to Cuba at a gathering of Western Hemisphere leaders in Trinidad capped a dizzying series of diplomatic developments this week.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad and Tobago  President Obama, seeking to thaw long-frozen relations with Cuba, told a gathering of Western Hemisphere leaders on Friday that “the United States seeks a new beginning with Cuba,” and that he was willing to have his administration engage the Castro government on a wide array of issues.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Alexei Barrionuevo

articles.headline: How a Personal Finance Columnist Got Caught Up in Fraud
articles.snippet: When a columnist’s financial planner comes under scrutiny, it’s time for a serious rethink.
articles.abstract: When a columnist’s financial planner comes under scrutiny, it’s time for a serious rethink.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Sunday, I returned from vacation, picked up the mail and found a disturbing letter from Charles Schwab & Company. It said that it had discovered unauthorized money transfers out of accounts associated with the financial planning firm I use.

articles.headline: Public Provides Giggles; Bloggers Get the Book Deal
articles.snippet: Publishers are hoping that millions of page views on a blog will translate into booming sales on the bookstand.
articles.abstract: Publishers are hoping that millions of page views on a blog will translate into booming sales on the bookstand.
articles.lead_paragraph: After Duncan Birmingham, a comedy screenwriter in Los Angeles, got one too many holiday cards featuring miserable-looking pets wearing fake reindeer antlers, he realized the photos were great material for a blog.

articles.headline: Divisions Arose on Rough Tactics for Qaeda Figure
articles.snippet: The decision to use brutal interrogation tactics against Abu Zubaydah was based on a highly inflated assessment of his importance, interviews and documents show.
articles.abstract: The decision to use brutal interrogation tactics against Abu Zubaydah was based on a highly inflated assessment of his importance, interviews and documents show.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The first use of waterboarding and other rough treatment against a prisoner from Al Qaeda was ordered by senior Central Intelligence Agency officials despite the belief of interrogators that the prisoner had already told them all he knew, according to former intelligence officials and a footnote in a newly released legal memorandum.

articles.headline: Business Grads Looking Beyond Wall Street
articles.snippet: Business students graduating this year know they are less likely to get a job offer in investment banking. For some, that’s liberating.
articles.abstract: Business students graduating this year know they are less likely to get a job offer in investment banking. For some, that’s liberating.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Riana Paige, an undergraduate senior at the Wharton School of Business, had a high-paying internship at JPMorgan Chase last summer and was disappointed when she did not receive an offer for a full-time job after graduation. Now she is pursuing a job teaching in Dubai, or working for a wine importer.

articles.headline: A Plan for U.S. Emissions to Be Buried Under Sea
articles.snippet: In an effort to fight global warming, one company proposes storing emissions from power plants in sandstone under the ocean floor.
articles.abstract: In an effort to fight global warming, one company proposes storing emissions from power plants in sandstone under the ocean floor.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an ambitious proposal to counter global warming, an upstart power developer wants to build a coal-fired electric plant on the outskirts of New York City that would capture its emissions of carbon dioxide and pump the pollutant 70 miles offshore. The gas would be injected into sandstone a mile beneath the ocean floor in the hope that it would stay there for eons.

articles.headline: Companies Reset Goals for Bonuses
articles.snippet: With companies falling short of their targets in tough times, top executives may miss out on bonuses. As a result, some companies are changing their measures of performance.
articles.abstract: With companies falling short of their targets in tough times, top executives may miss out on bonuses. As a result, some companies are changing their measures of performance.
articles.lead_paragraph: When executives have a tough time meeting their performance goals, a growing number of companies are moving the goalposts for them.

articles.headline: Lawmakers May Limit Paper Mills’ Windfall
articles.snippet: Papermakers who use wood byproducts to power their plants are earning up to a billion dollars in tax credits by mixing some diesel fuel into their natural fuel.
articles.abstract: Papermakers who use wood byproducts to power their plants are earning up to a billion dollars in tax credits by mixing some diesel fuel into their natural fuel.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senior lawmakers in Washington said Friday they would look into repealing or limiting an obscure tax provision that is turning into an unintended, billion-dollar windfall for companies that manufacture paper.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Secure Enough to Sin, Baghdad Revisits Old Ways
articles.snippet: With curfews, kidnappings and religious extremists less of a concern, more Iraqis are rediscovering illicit pleasures.
articles.abstract: With curfews, kidnappings and religious extremists less of a concern, more Iraqis are rediscovering illicit pleasures.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Vice is making a comeback in this city once famous for 1,001 varieties of it.

articles.headline: Make Room, Cynics; MTV Wants to Do Some Good
articles.snippet: After years of celebrating the excesses of youth, MTV is adding shows with a veneer of positive social messages.
articles.abstract: After years of celebrating the excesses of youth, MTV is adding shows with a veneer of positive social messages.
articles.lead_paragraph: Four buddies set off across the country in an R.V., video camera in tow, to knock items off their “100 things to do before I die” list: kiss the Stanley Cup, get a tattoo, grow a mustache.

articles.headline: Struggling to Rise in Suburbs Where Failing Means Fitting In
articles.snippet: One in four American youths is an immigrant or a child of one, and a troubled minority of them offers cause for alarm.
articles.abstract: One in four American youths is an immigrant or a child of one, and a troubled minority of them offers cause for alarm.
articles.lead_paragraph: LANGLEY PARK, Md.  Class at the youth center had just let out, and a gaggle of teenagers moved toward the door, turning saggy pants and ring tones thrumming with reggaetón hits into adolescent statements of Latino cool.

articles.headline: F.B.I. and States Vastly Expand DNA Databases
articles.snippet: The expansion of DNA collection to include millions of people who have been arrested or detained but not convicted is raising privacy concerns.
articles.abstract: The expansion of DNA collection to include millions of people who have been arrested or detained but not convicted is raising privacy concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: Law enforcement officials are vastly expanding their collection of DNA to include millions more people who have been arrested or detained but not yet convicted. The move, intended to help solve more crimes, is raising concerns about the privacy of petty offenders and people who are presumed innocent.

articles.headline: When the Real Estate Game Cost $9.95
articles.snippet: For millions of real estate wannabes, Carleton Sheets’s infomercials embodied the bubble as much as Citigroup or Merrill Lynch did.
articles.abstract: For millions of real estate wannabes, Carleton Sheets’s infomercials embodied the bubble as much as Citigroup or Merrill Lynch did.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN the alternate universe of late-night TV infomercials, Carleton H. Sheets once reigned supreme. Standing against a backdrop of tropical seas and gently swaying palm trees, he promised that viewers, no matter how down on their luck, could soar into the ranks of the super-rich by investing in that most bubblicious of assets: real estate.

articles.headline: The Funeral: Your Last Chance to Be a Big Spender
articles.snippet: A willingness to cater to individual tastes is helping the funeral industry hold its own during the recession.
articles.abstract: A willingness to cater to individual tastes is helping the funeral industry hold its own during the recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: EVEN in these hard times, Peter Moloney, a funeral director, believes that people should have what they want.

articles.headline: Despite Major Plans, Obama Taking Softer Stands
articles.snippet: After pledges to change Washington, the president’s early willingness to deal or fold has left commentators and allies wondering: where’s the fight?
articles.abstract: After pledges to change Washington, the president’s early willingness to deal or fold has left commentators and allies wondering: where’s the fight?
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama is well known for bold proposals that have raised expectations, but his administration has shown a tendency for compromise and caution, and even a willingness to capitulate on some early initiatives.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Jackie Calmes

articles.headline: Hungary’s Spirits Are Back Up, on a Horse
articles.snippet: Overdose, a thoroughbred bought for a pittance, has turned into a national hero in Hungary.
articles.abstract: Overdose, a thoroughbred bought for a pittance, has turned into a national hero in Hungary.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — A racehorse bought for a pittance has turned into a national hero in crisis-stricken Hungary.

articles.headline: Investors Air Discontent With Bank of America
articles.snippet: Longtime shareholders, some of them families that owned Bank of America’s legacy banks, are alarmed by the daunting challenges confronting the company.
articles.abstract: Longtime shareholders, some of them families that owned Bank of America’s legacy banks, are alarmed by the daunting challenges confronting the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than 70 years, through good times and bad, the Eliasberg family stood by their bank. Their tiny lender grew up to become part of what is now Bank of America  tying the family’s fortunes to that of the nation’s largest bank.

articles.headline: Cable Wars Are Killing Objectivity
articles.snippet: The coverage of the tax day tea parties augured a return to the days of the party press, where news outlets reflected viewpoints of specific wings of political thought.
articles.abstract: The coverage of the tax day tea parties augured a return to the days of the party press, where news outlets reflected viewpoints of specific wings of political thought.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apparently there is an ingredient in tea that causes hysteria when given to cable news anchors. How else to explain the coverage of the tax day tea parties on Wednesday, which was the day when we procrastinators finally mailed the check to the feds?

articles.headline: Pinned Down, a Sprint to Escape Taliban Zone
articles.snippet: Ambushed by Taliban fighters, American soldiers fought their way out of a riverbed, and then grieved the loss of one of their own.
articles.abstract: Ambushed by Taliban fighters, American soldiers fought their way out of a riverbed, and then grieved the loss of one of their own.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALIABAD, Afghanistan — The two Army lieutenants crouched against boulders beside the Korangal River. Taliban gunfire poured down from villages and cliffs above, hitting tree branches and rocks and snapping as the bullets passed over the officers’ helmets.

articles.headline: 3 Trustees of A.I.G. Are Quiet, Perhaps to a Fault
articles.snippet: For all their responsibility, the government’s overseers at American International Group have studiously remained invisible to the public.
articles.abstract: For all their responsibility, the government’s overseers at American International Group have studiously remained invisible to the public.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In an early sign of just how tricky corporate governance has become in the era of taxpayer bailouts, three little-known trustees with no office, no staff and almost no mission will soon be deciding questions that affect the fate of American International Group, the giant insurance company.

articles.headline: U.S. May Convert Banks’ Bailouts to Equity Share
articles.snippet: Obama administration officials say the approach will allow them to shore up the nation’s banking system without seeking more money from Congress.
articles.abstract: Obama administration officials say the approach will allow them to shore up the nation’s banking system without seeking more money from Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama’s top economic advisers have determined that they can shore up the nation’s banking system without having to ask Congress for more money any time soon, according to administration officials.

articles.headline: Waterboarding Used 266 Times on 2 Suspects
articles.snippet: C.I.A. interrogators used the near-drowning technique, which Obama administration officials have described as torture, 266 times on two key prisoners from Al Qaeda.
articles.abstract: C.I.A. interrogators used the near-drowning technique, which Obama administration officials have described as torture, 266 times on two key prisoners from Al Qaeda.
articles.lead_paragraph: C.I.A. interrogators used waterboarding, the near-drowning technique that top Obama administration officials have described as illegal torture, 266 times on two key prisoners from Al Qaeda, far more than had been previously reported.

articles.headline: The Older Audience Is Looking Better Than Ever
articles.snippet: Demographic shifts and a recession are making older consumers — long shunned in favor of free-spending, younger age groups — into better bets.
articles.abstract: Demographic shifts and a recession are making older consumers — long shunned in favor of free-spending, younger age groups — into better bets.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Brian Gordon and his partners started ebeanstalk.com, which sells children’s learning toys online, they expected most of business to come from younger consumers starting families. But a recent customer survey found that up to 40 percent were actually older, mainly grandparents.

articles.headline: As Costs Fall, Companies Push to Raise Internet Price
articles.snippet: Cable Internet providers want to implement tiered pricing to charge more for heavy use, despite steady profits and the companies’ falling costs.
articles.abstract: Cable Internet providers want to implement tiered pricing to charge more for heavy use, despite steady profits and the companies’ falling costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Internet service providers want to end the all-you-can-eat plans and get their customers paying à la carte.

articles.headline: Sellers Woo Shoppers With Guarantees to Address Layoff Worries
articles.snippet: To get nervous consumers to buy, companies are promising refunds, and sometimes more, in the event of a job loss.
articles.abstract: To get nervous consumers to buy, companies are promising refunds, and sometimes more, in the event of a job loss.
articles.lead_paragraph: First, retailers enticed struggling consumers with deep discounts. Then they dangled buy-one-get-one free deals.

articles.headline: Profit Up, Bank of America Chief Cites Acquisitions
articles.snippet: The bank said its $4.2 billion profit showed the value of acquiring Merrill Lynch and Countrywide, but its shares fell because much of the profit came from accounting changes.
articles.abstract: The bank said its $4.2 billion profit showed the value of acquiring Merrill Lynch and Countrywide, but its shares fell because much of the profit came from accounting changes.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a strong rally lifted financial stocks 80 percent in just six weeks, Wall Street is once again becoming nervous about the big banks.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy and Louise Story
